'''Luke Bell''' (January 27, 1990 – August 26, 2022) was an American [[country music|country]] musician and singer-songwriter.<ref name="AllMusic-bio">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/luke-bell-mn0002487881/biography |title=Luke Bell – Biography |last=Monger |first=Timothy |date= |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=September 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="wyomingpublicradio">{{cite web |last1=Smith |first1=Marie |title=Luke Bell Music Review |url=http://wyomingpublicmedia.org/post/luke-bell-music-review |website=Wyoming Public Media |date=April 30, 2013 |accessdate=September 1, 2018}}</ref> According to ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Bell "[played] classic honky-tonk with a wink and a yodel that summons the sleeping ghosts of country better than any voodoo spell ever could".<ref name="rollingstone">{{cite magazine |title=CMA Music Fest 2015: 25 Must-See Acts |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/cma-music-fest-2015-25-must-see-acts-165101/?list_page=1#list-item-21 |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=June 10, 2015 |accessdate=September 1, 2018}}</ref>

==Early life==
Bell was born in [[Lexington, Kentucky]], and raised in [[Cody, Wyoming]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Avila |first=Pamela |date=2022-08-31 |title=Luke Bell, country singer known for hits 'Where Ya Been?' and 'Jealous Guy', found dead at 32 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/celebrities/2022/08/31/luke-bell-country-singer-found-dead-arizona-missing/7945653001/ |work=[[USA Today]] |quote=Born in Lexington, Kentucky, on Jan. 27, 1990, Bell...was raised in Cody, Wyoming... |access-date=2022-08-31}}</ref> He attended [[Cody High School (Wyoming)|Cody High School]], graduating in 2008. Bell briefly attended college in [[Laramie, Wyoming]], before dropping out.

==Career==
===Debut self-titled album===
Bell moved to [[Austin, Texas]], in 2012 where he recorded his self-titled debut album.<ref>{{cite web |last=Morris |first=Corey |title=Bell concert at Inn on Saturday raises money for album |url=http://www.codyenterprise.com/news/people/article_2cd59196-159a-11e3-9678-0019bb2963f4.html |website=[[Cody Enterprise]] |date=September 4, 2013 |accessdate=September 3, 2018}}</ref><ref name="pastemagazine1">{{cite web |last1=Sforzini |first1=Hank |title=Nine Wyoming Bands You Should Listen to Now |date=September 10, 2014 |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/music/wyoming/nine-wyoming-bands-you-should-listen-to-now/#7-luke-bell- |publisher=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |access-date=1 September 2022}}</ref> Bell also produced the entire album himself.<ref name="wyomingpublicradio"/>

===''Don't Mind If I Do''===
Bell moved to [[New Orleans]] briefly, where he spent his time busking on the street to make money.<ref name="pastemagazine1"/> Afterwards, he moved back to Cody, Wyoming, where he wrote and recorded his second full-length album, titled ''Don't Mind If I Do''. He wrote the album while working on a ranch, and recorded it upon receiving funding from a [[Kickstarter]] campaign.<ref name="pastemagazine1"/>

Bell enlisted Andrija Tokic, who had worked with [[Caitlin Rose]], [[Alabama Shakes]], and [[Hurray for the Riff Raff]] previously, to produce the album.<ref name="pastemagazine1"/> He recorded a [[Daytrotter]] session that same year. According to Daytrotter, the people whom Bell writes about "have bigger than life personalities" and "Bell is, without a doubt, one of the most talented country and western songwriters working ..."<ref name="pastemagazine">{{cite web |title=Luke Bell – Don't Mind If I Do |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/02/luke-bell-dont-mind-if-i-do23.html |website=[[Paste Magazine]] |author=Daytrotter |date=February 16, 2015 |accessdate=September 1, 2018 |archive-date=August 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805145631/http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/02/luke-bell-dont-mind-if-i-do23.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>

===Final album===
After the second record era was complete, Bell moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name="sandiegotribune">{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Randy |title=Stagecoach 2016: Backstage with Luke Bell |date=May 2016 |url=https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/sdut-stagecoach-indio-luke-bell-2016apr30-story.html |publisher=[[San Diego Tribune]] |access-date=1 September 2022}}</ref> He released his second self-titled and third and final studio album in 2016.<ref name="theboot">{{cite web |last1=Armstrong |first1=Chuck |title=Interview: Luke Bell Chats About His New LP, Why He Still Enjoys Listening to His Own Music |date=June 17, 2016 |url=https://theboot.com/luke-bell-new-music-interview-2016/ |publisher=The Boot |access-date=1 September 2022}}</ref> The album was a mix of songs from his previous album and new songs.

"Sometimes", a single from the album that was originally on Bell's 2014 release, received attention from both NPR Music<ref name="nprmusic">{{cite web |last1=Gotrich |first1=Lars |title=Got A Broken Heart? Hit The Karaoke Bar With Luke Bell's 'Sometimes' |website=NPR |date=April 20, 2016 |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/04/20/474807133/got-a-broken-heart-hit-the-karaoke-bar-with-luke-bells-sometimes |publisher=[[NPR Music]] |access-date=1 September 2022}}</ref> and ''Rolling Stone''.<ref name="rollingstone2">{{cite web |last1=Leahey |first1=Andrew |title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: May 2016 |date=May 4, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-may-2016-69769/luke-bell-2-28920/ |publisher=Rolling Stone |access-date=1 September 2022}}</ref> A music video featuring [[Erin Rae]], [[Patrick Sweany]], and Kristina Murray was released for the song.<ref name="nprmusic"/> In late 2016, Bell released a cover of the 1971 [[John Lennon]] song "[[Jealous Guy]]".<ref name="rollingstone1">{{cite web |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen |title=See Luke Bell's Forlorn Cover of John Lennon's 'Jealous Guy' |date=November 4, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-luke-bells-forlorn-cover-of-john-lennons-jealous-guy-111596/ |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=1 September 2022}}</ref>

==Death==
While in [[Tucson, Arizona]], Bell disappeared on August 20, 2022, while his friend went out to eat.<ref>{{cite web |title=Luke Bell Dead at 32: 5 Things to Know About the Country Star Who Disappeared|url=https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/luke-bell-dead-at-32-5-things-to-know-about-the-country-star/ |website=usmagazine.com|date=August 31, 2022 }}</ref> He was found dead in Tucson nine days later, not far from where he disappeared, aged 32. Bell suffered from severe [[bipolar disorder]] and had recently changed medication for treatment prior to his death.<ref>{{cite web |title=Country Singer Luke Bell Dead At 32 After He Was Reported Missing in Arizona |url=https://www.intouchweekly.com/posts/luke-bell-dead-at-32-country-singer-dies-after-missing/ |website=InTouchWeekly.com|date=August 30, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| last = Tapp| first = Tom| title = Luke Bell Dies: Country Singer Who Went Missing 10 Days Ago Found Dead At 32| work = Deadline| accessdate = 2022-09-01| date = 2022-08-31| url = https://deadline.com/2022/08/luke-bell-dead-country-singer-1235103883/}}</ref>

His family released a statement a few days later confirming his bipolar disorder contributed to his death. However, they did not give a specific cause of his death.<ref>{{cite web |title=Luke Bell's Family Speaks Out About Mental Health After His Death at 32: 'We Are Heartbroken' |url=https://people.com/country/luke-bell-family-talks-mental-health-illness-after-his-death-at-age-32/ |website=People.com}}</ref> On September 18, 2022, the Pima County Medical Examiner's Office announced that Bell had died from [[fentanyl]] intoxication on August 26.<ref name="KGUN" />
